awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Institutional Transformation at Seattle University
awd_abstract_narration:
The ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of women faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in areas such as policy, practice, culture, and organizational climate.  The ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (ADVANCE-IT) track supports the development of innovative organizational change strategies within an institution of higher education to enhance gender equity in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

Seattle University (SU) will implement an ADVANCE-IT project that will align institutional core values of teaching, service, and engagement with the standards for faculty evaluation and advancement.  SU is a predominantly undergraduate institution and a university whose values emphasize service and community engagement.  They plan a number of initiatives to ensure alignment of these values with faculty related programs, policies, and practices.  These strategies include: assessing and revising the current standards for promotion including options for multiple tracks to success; working with faculty leaders and university administrators in the articulation of the central themes of the project and strategic communication; implementation of formal training programs for faculty mentors; and training for promotion committees by adapting the Georgia Tech strategy called Awareness of Decisions in Evaluating Promotion and Tenure (ADEPT).  

The project is grounded in a theory of change that views gender as a part of organizational structures, and that aims to change university policies, practices, and culture in ways that foster equity for faculty.  The focus on the connection between institutional mission, evaluation practices, and gender equity is innovative.  This project could provide a model for restructuring standards of academic advancement in ways that recognize the work of institutional service that often falls disproportionately on women and underrepresented faculty.  The project includes a research component that will contribute to the literature on the relationship between gender equity and standards of faculty evaluation and promotion.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
A significant barrier to advancement for women and faculty of color is disproportionate engagement in activities that contribute directly to the health of higher education, but which do not count for promotion. In 1957, sociologist Alvin Gouldner characterized faculty culture as a status distinction between "cosmopolitans" and "locals." The former cultivated recognition through individually competitive research careers. The latter performed the "hidden work" foundational to higher education: teaching, mentoring, and institutional leadership. Cosmopolitans advanced rapidly to become "stars" worthy of the university's highest accolades; the contributions of the locals were taken-for-granted and unacknowledged. Nearly 70 years later, this divide is an entrenched, unexamined culture whereby colleges and universities are unable to recognize and reward the diverse range of activities that constitute faculty careers, especially among women and faculty of color.

From 2016-2022, SU ADVANCE has focused on transforming this culture of "hidden work" through cultural education and policy change. We initially proposed to revise the university standards for promotion to Professor to include activities that directly benefit students, universities, and communities, but which are not easily captured in traditional measures of impact. We developed and implemented this extensive policy change and have seen impressive results in the number of women and faculty of color petitioning successfully for promotion in the past two years since the policy took effect (from an average of 1-2 petitions per year over the past twenty years to 11 in 2021, 9 in 2022, and an expected 15 in 2023). We are also having impact in the cultural intervention of raising awareness of and appreciation for comprehensive, holistic faculty careers as the hub of a vibrant university.

 Our three-phase approach to institutional transformation uses a multi-dimensional model of organizational change and participatory action research (PAR) methodology. Phase One involved "strategic communication" and institutional ethnography with the aim of disrupting cultural ideals about what "counts" in faculty advancement.  Our working hypothesis was that, while faculty and administrators appreciate diversity-centered, student-oriented, institution-building contributions in a mission-focused university such as SU, they equate these contributions with "service" and discount them as "real" accomplishments worthy of promotion.  This hypothesis was confirmed repeatedly in the groups we convened across all levels of the university. As one senior leader put it, "of course we value these activities... people should get a plaque or something, but it's not a line to promotion." This faculty culture views mission activities as necessary, but not in line with the "rigor" expected of research-focused faculty i.e., to reward the former is to "dumb down" the latter. Using our PAR approach, we then shared these observations in second-round discussions intended to disrupt unexamined beliefs.

We also conducted 77 in-depth faculty interviews and two focus groups with Associate Professors. These interviews revealed considerable cognitive dissonance and distress around how best to allocate energy and organize careers in an institution that expresses a liberal arts mission orientation, but doesn't reward the activities aligned with this mission.  As one person stated, "I love the mission, but it's killing me." This misalignment is exacerbated by emphases on DEI work, which women and faculty of color disproportionately engage in, but which typically doesn?t count toward advancement.

 Phase Two focused on developing and implementing new promotion standards. A task force consisting of deans, faculty, and other stakeholders met regularly to draft standards reflective of the comprehensive range of contributions revealed through the research undertaken in phase one. The result is a "Holistic Faculty Development Plan" that has been reviewed at each level of faculty governance and ratified through the Faculty Senate.

 Phase Three (ongoing) focuses on mentoring faculty to articulate intentional career paths that integrate historically undervalued activities and to make the case for the value of these activities under the new promotion guidelines. Corresponding training with deans, department chairs, and faculty evaluation committees raises awareness of the value of these contributions and provides guidance in how to recognize and assess faculty contributions holistically.

 An additional PAR-grounded outcome was delineating four categories of undervalued faculty activity: public/applied scholarship; community-engaged scholarship; institution building (e.g., significant faculty administrative leadership); and DEI-centered activities. A corollary barrier to promotion is lack of assessment tools for these diverse faculty contributions toward advancement, beyond traditional, easily standardized measures. Supported by a recently granted ADVANCE Partnership award, our next effort is developing an assessment toolkit for these activities.  

 What began as a project of enacting policy changes that acknowledge hidden but essential contributions, has resulted in university-wide awareness of the benefits of revisioning the professoriate with holistic focus. SU ADVANCE is now an anchor in the university five-year strategic plan. We have also developed productive relationships with other ADVANCE-IT grantee institutions. As part of our dissemination practice, we have engaged vigorously with institutions seeking to replicate our efforts and will continue to do so into the future.
